d1t1.title: The Conflict Resolution Challenge
d1t1.projectContext: You're the PM on a 6-month enterprise software project with a team of 12. The project is in its early execution phase with a $2M budget. Your goal: deliver the customer portal by Q3.

decisions.narrative: Two senior developers disagree on the architecture approach. One wants microservices, the other a monolith. The debate is getting heated in stand-ups and affecting team morale.

options.text: Facilitate a structured debate with decision criteria
options.feedback: Collaborative conflict resolution builds trust. The Thomas-Kilmann collaborating approach invests time upfront but creates buy-in and a stronger solution.

options.text: Make the architecture decision yourself based on technical merit
options.feedback: A forcing/directing approach saves time but may reduce team ownership. As PM, overriding technical experts can damage credibility.

options.text: Ask each developer to prototype their approach for comparison
options.feedback: Prototyping provides evidence-based decisions but costs time and budget. This is a compromising approach with tangible evaluation criteria.

options.text: Escalate to the technical lead to make the final call
options.feedback: Delegating up avoids direct resolution and can undermine your authority. The Thomas-Kilmann avoiding style doesn't build team conflict resolution skills.

decisions.narrative: The QA lead and a developer are in open conflict about testing standards. The developer says the QA requirements are excessive and slowing velocity. QA insists on thoroughness.

options.text: Hold a joint session to define mutually acceptable quality criteria
options.feedback: Collaborating to define shared standards addresses root causes. Integrative negotiation finds solutions that satisfy both parties' core interests.

options.text: Implement a tiered testing approach - critical paths get full QA, others get lighter review
options.feedback: Compromising gives each side something. Risk-based testing is pragmatic but may miss edge cases in lower-tier features.

options.text: Back the QA lead's standards since quality is non-negotiable
options.feedback: Accommodating QA reduces risk but forcing one side's view without discussion breeds resentment. The developer's velocity concerns remain unaddressed.

options.text: Let them work it out between themselves
options.feedback: Avoiding intervention lets conflict fester. Without facilitation, interpersonal conflicts rarely resolve constructively and can spread to other team members.

decisions.narrative: A scope change request from the sponsor creates friction. Half the team wants to embrace the change for a better product; the other half fears scope creep and burnout.

options.text: Run a team impact assessment workshop before responding to the sponsor
options.feedback: Including the team in impact analysis respects their expertise and addresses concerns. This is collaborative conflict management combined with proper change control.

options.text: Accept the change but negotiate additional time and resources from the sponsor
options.feedback: Negotiating resources shows sponsor management skills. However, not involving the team in the decision may not address the underlying tension.

options.text: Push back on the sponsor with data showing current scope risk
options.feedback: Protecting the team from scope creep builds trust, but saying no to sponsors requires strong political capital. Use data-driven arguments per change control best practices.

options.text: Split the change into must-have and nice-to-have, implementing only essentials now
options.feedback: MoSCoW prioritization is a pragmatic compromise. It partially satisfies both camps but may leave the full conflict unresolved for later iterations.

decisions.narrative: Two sub-teams working on integrated modules blame each other for integration failures. Finger-pointing is replacing problem-solving. Daily stand-ups have become tense.

options.text: Establish a joint integration team with members from both sides
options.feedback: Creating shared ownership dissolves us-vs-them dynamics. Cross-functional collaboration is a key agile principle that addresses systemic integration conflicts.

options.text: Implement automated integration testing to provide objective failure data
options.feedback: Removing blame through objective data is excellent. Automated testing provides facts, but the initial investment is significant. This addresses symptoms and root cause.

options.text: Hold a retrospective focused specifically on integration challenges
options.feedback: Retrospectives are a core agile practice for addressing team conflicts. Focusing on process rather than people depersonalizes the conflict.

options.text: Restructure the teams so integration responsibility is clearly assigned
options.feedback: Organizational restructuring clarifies accountability but disrupts established working relationships. RACI matrices help, but mid-project changes carry transition costs.

decisions.narrative: As delivery approaches, the client's project manager and your team disagree on acceptance criteria interpretation. Both sides believe the contract supports their view.

options.text: Propose a joint requirements review with both teams and documented agreements
options.feedback: Collaborative conflict resolution with documentation prevents future disputes. Joint reviews build shared understanding per stakeholder engagement best practices.

options.text: Engage a neutral third party to mediate the interpretation dispute
options.feedback: Third-party mediation is appropriate for entrenched positions. It's costly but preserves the relationship. Mediation is a formal conflict resolution escalation technique.

options.text: Defer to the contract language and have legal review the acceptance criteria
options.feedback: Legal review protects your organization but can damage the client relationship. Contractual forcing should be a last resort per procurement management principles.

options.text: Offer to deliver the disputed items as the client interprets them if timeline extends
options.feedback: Accommodating the client builds goodwill but sets a precedent. This smoothing approach may encourage future scope interpretation disputes.

d1t2.title: The Leadership Crucible
d1t2.projectContext: You're leading a new product development team of 15 across three time zones. The 9-month project involves building an IoT-enabled smart home device. Budget is $3.5M with aggressive go-to-market targets.

decisions.narrative: Your team is newly formed from different departments. They're waiting for direction but you want to establish a leadership style early. The team has mixed experience levels.

options.text: Hold a vision-setting workshop where the team co-creates project goals and working agreements
options.feedback: Servant leadership starts with shared vision. This participative approach aligns with the PMBOK emphasis on collaborative leadership and builds intrinsic motivation.

options.text: Present a clear project charter with defined roles, milestones, and expectations
options.feedback: Directive leadership provides clarity and structure, especially useful in Tuckman's forming stage. Clear expectations reduce ambiguity but may limit creative ownership.

options.text: Schedule one-on-ones with each team member to understand their strengths and motivations
options.feedback: Individualized consideration is a key transformational leadership behavior. Understanding team members enables better role assignment but takes time upfront.

options.text: Assign a challenging quick-win task to build team momentum and confidence
options.feedback: Early wins build confidence and team identity. This is an effective leadership technique during forming, though it may rush past important team-building steps.

decisions.narrative: The hardware and software sub-teams are developing in silos. Communication gaps are causing design misalignment. You notice the teams have different working cultures.

options.text: Establish cross-functional sync meetings and shared integration milestones
options.feedback: Structural integration points address systemic communication gaps. As a leader, creating frameworks for collaboration is more sustainable than ad hoc interventions.

options.text: Create shared physical/virtual spaces where teams interact informally
options.feedback: Osmotic communication, an agile principle, reduces information silos. Informal interactions build rapport across cultural boundaries but take time to show results.

options.text: Rotate team members between hardware and software for short assignments
options.feedback: Cross-training builds empathy and T-shaped skills. However, the short-term productivity loss during rotation can impact tight schedules. This is a long-term leadership investment.

options.text: Appoint integration liaisons from each team to coordinate daily
options.feedback: Liaison roles create clear communication channels without disrupting team structures. However, this can create bottlenecks if liaisons become single points of contact.

decisions.narrative: A key team member is underperforming and missing deadlines. Others are picking up the slack and growing resentful. You've heard rumors they're dealing with personal issues.

options.text: Have a private, empathetic conversation to understand the situation and offer support
options.feedback: Emotional intelligence and empathy are core leadership competencies. Understanding root causes before acting prevents unfair judgment and builds psychological safety.

options.text: Redistribute work temporarily and set clear performance expectations with a timeline
options.feedback: Balanced approach addresses both team needs and individual fairness. Setting expectations with support is situational leadership - adjusting style to the person's needs.

options.text: Pair them with a senior team member for mentoring and workload sharing
options.feedback: Mentoring pairs address performance through support rather than pressure. This develops the team but adds load to the senior member. Ensure the mentor has capacity.

options.text: Formally document performance concerns and engage HR for guidance
options.feedback: Documentation protects the project and organization but can feel punitive. Jumping to formal processes without first exploring support options may damage trust across the team.

decisions.narrative: The team has hit a major technical obstacle. Morale is low. Some team members are suggesting the project pivot to a simpler design. The sponsor is pushing for the original ambitious scope.

options.text: Facilitate a structured problem-solving session with time-boxed brainstorming
options.feedback: Leading through adversity by empowering the team to solve problems demonstrates servant leadership. Facilitated brainstorming leverages collective intelligence.

options.text: Bring in an external technical expert to assess options and advise
options.feedback: External expertise can break through technical impasses. This shows leadership humility - knowing when the team needs outside help. Budget impact is a trade-off for risk reduction.

options.text: Present the sponsor with a data-driven analysis of options including the pivot
options.feedback: Transparent upward communication is essential leadership. Presenting options with data respects the sponsor's authority while providing the information for good decisions.

options.text: Rally the team with a motivational approach - celebrate progress and reaffirm the vision
options.feedback: Inspirational motivation is a transformational leadership behavior. However, positivity without a concrete plan can feel dismissive of real technical concerns.

decisions.narrative: The project is entering final testing. The team is exhausted from months of intense work. You need sustained high performance for 6 more weeks but burnout signs are everywhere.

options.text: Implement sustainable pace practices - limit overtime, add buffer time, rotate on-call duties
options.feedback: Sustainable pace is an agile principle. Protecting team wellbeing may extend the timeline but reduces burnout risk and defect rates during critical testing phases.

options.text: Negotiate with the sponsor for temporary additional resources to share the load
options.feedback: Adding resources late follows Brooks's Law risk, but temporary focused support can help. Leadership means advocating for your team's capacity needs.

options.text: Create a visible countdown with team celebrations at each milestone
options.feedback: Recognition and milestone celebrations sustain motivation. Gamification of progress leverages intrinsic and extrinsic motivators during demanding periods.

options.text: Hold candid team discussion about workload and let the team propose solutions
options.feedback: Empowering the team to solve their own burnout demonstrates trust and servant leadership. Teams often find creative solutions leaders wouldn't consider.

d1t3.title: The Performance Optimization Sprint
d1t3.projectContext: You're managing a 12-person marketing analytics platform rebuild. The 8-month project is at $1.5M budget. Your team includes data engineers, UX designers, and marketing specialists.

decisions.narrative: Sprint velocity is inconsistent. Some team members finish early while others struggle with their stories. Estimation accuracy is poor and the team lacks a shared definition of done.

options.text: Introduce relative estimation with planning poker and refine the definition of done collaboratively
options.feedback: Planning poker improves estimation through collective wisdom. A shared definition of done aligns quality expectations. Both are core Scrum practices for performance support.

options.text: Analyze individual velocity data and rebalance workload assignments
options.feedback: Data-driven workload balancing is efficient but measuring individual velocity can feel like surveillance. Agile philosophy emphasizes team velocity over individual metrics.

options.text: Pair experienced team members with those struggling for knowledge transfer
options.feedback: Pair programming and mentoring build capability. Short-term velocity dips as pairs form, but long-term team performance increases. This invests in team capacity.

options.text: Break stories into smaller, more uniform sizes to improve flow predictability
options.feedback: Story slicing improves flow and predictability per lean/kanban principles. Smaller work items reduce variability and make bottlenecks visible earlier.

decisions.narrative: The team's retrospectives have become stale. People repeat the same issues but nothing changes. Attendance is dropping and some call them a waste of time.

options.text: Redesign the retro format with new facilitation techniques and rotating facilitators
options.feedback: Variety in retrospective formats maintains engagement. Rotating facilitators builds facilitation skills. Try formats like sailboat, 4Ls, or timeline retrospectives.

options.text: Create an action item tracker with owners and follow up on previous commitments
options.feedback: Accountability for action items is crucial. Teams lose faith in retrospectives when nothing changes. Tracking and follow-through demonstrate continuous improvement commitment.

options.text: Replace formal retros with continuous feedback channels and periodic team health checks
options.feedback: Continuous feedback can be more timely than periodic retros. Team health checks (like Spotify's model) provide structured ongoing assessment. But losing dedicated reflection time has risks.

options.text: Have an honest discussion about why retros feel ineffective and what the team actually needs
options.feedback: Meta-retrospective on the retro process itself models the inspect-and-adapt mindset. Addressing team frustration directly builds psychological safety and trust.

decisions.narrative: The team has plateaued. They're delivering consistently but not improving. Innovation has stalled and they're comfortable with the status quo. Technical debt is accumulating.

options.text: Allocate 20% of sprint capacity to innovation and technical debt reduction
options.feedback: Dedicated innovation time prevents stagnation and addresses technical debt proactively. Google's 20% time concept keeps teams engaged and reduces long-term risk.

options.text: Introduce stretch goals and team-level performance incentives
options.feedback: Stretch goals can reignite ambition per goal-setting theory. However, external incentives may crowd out intrinsic motivation. Ensure goals are challenging but achievable.

options.text: Bring in guest speakers or arrange cross-team learning sessions
options.feedback: Exposure to new ideas combats groupthink and complacency. Communities of practice and knowledge sharing are organizational learning best practices.

options.text: Conduct a skills gap analysis and create individual development plans
options.feedback: Individual development plans support mastery, a key intrinsic motivator per Daniel Pink's Drive model. Skills gap analysis ensures targeted, relevant growth.

decisions.narrative: A critical team member has resigned. They hold key domain knowledge about the legacy system being replaced. The team is shaken and worried about meeting deadlines.

options.text: Negotiate an extended notice period and intensive knowledge transfer sessions
options.feedback: Knowledge transfer during transition mitigates the bus factor risk. Documentation and pair sessions capture tacit knowledge. This is a key risk response strategy.

options.text: Redistribute responsibilities and empower the team to fill the gap collectively
options.feedback: Collective ownership reduces key-person dependency. Empowering the team to step up builds resilience. This follows the agile principle of self-organizing teams.

options.text: Fast-track hiring a replacement with relevant domain expertise
options.feedback: Replacing critical skills is prudent resource management. However, new team members take time to onboard per Tuckman's model. Budget for the hiring and ramp-up period.

options.text: Adjust the project plan and communicate revised expectations to stakeholders
options.feedback: Transparent replanning shows mature project management. Adjusting expectations proactively maintains stakeholder trust even with bad news. Manage expectations early.

decisions.narrative: The final integration phase reveals that one sub-team's component has significantly more defects than others. That team feels singled out and defensive. Other teams are frustrated.

options.text: Conduct a blameless post-mortem to understand systemic causes of the quality gap
options.feedback: Blameless post-mortems focus on process improvement, not finger-pointing. This is a DevOps and SRE best practice that maintains psychological safety while addressing quality.

options.text: Organize a team-wide bug bash where everyone helps fix defects regardless of origin
options.feedback: Collective ownership of quality reinforces that the project succeeds or fails as a team. Bug bashes build cross-component knowledge and team solidarity.

options.text: Add targeted code reviews and testing support for the struggling component
options.feedback: Focused quality gates address the immediate risk. Code reviews are a proven quality practice. Be careful to frame this as support rather than oversight.

options.text: Reassess the timeline and add a stabilization sprint before release
options.feedback: A hardening sprint addresses quality at the cost of schedule. This is a pragmatic approach but signals that quality wasn't baked in. Stakeholders may question the delay.
